en_results_raw: The flickering candles cast eerie shadows on the walls as she stood frozen, her eyes fixed on the group, her presence a stark contrast to the merriment that had been building all evening. The men, usually so confident and boisterous, now seemed to shrink under her gaze, their laughter dying on their lips as they sensed the weight of her disapproval. The air was heavy with tension, the only sound the soft crackling of the flames and the woman's steady, accusatory breathing. She was a specter of disapproval, a harbinger of doom, and the men knew it. They exchanged nervous glances, their smiles faltering as they wondered what they had done to incur her wrath. The woman's silence was a palpable thing, a living, breathing entity that seemed to pulse with an otherworldly energy. It was as if she had tapped into a deep well of resentment, a reservoir of anger that had been building for years, and now it was about to overflow. The men shifted uncomfortably, their eyes darting towards the door, hoping for an escape from the woman's piercing stare. But she stood firm, her eyes never leaving theirs, her silence a challenge, a dare to break the spell that had held them enthralled for so long. The room was a powder keg, waiting for a spark to set it off, and the woman's silence was the match that could ignite the flames of chaos.

El vehículo había desaparecido en la niebla que se elevaba del asfalto, y Montag se preguntó si había sido un sueño, pero el dolor en su cabeza le recordó que no lo era. Se puso de pie, tambaleándose un poco, y comenzó a caminar hacia la orilla del camino, donde se detuvo para mirar hacia atrás, esperando ver el vehículo reaparecer, pero no había nada. La niebla se elevaba en la oscuridad, como una niebla de fantasmas, y Montag sintió un escalofrío en la espalda. Se dio la vuelta y siguió caminando, intentando encontrar su camino de regreso a casa, pero la oscuridad parecía haberse cerrado sobre él como una mano invisible, y no podía ver más allá de unos pocos metros. La niebla parecía estar creciendo, envolviendo todo a su alrededor, y Montag se sintió perdido y solo en la oscuridad.

Some of them looked up at the sky, as if searching for the jets that had unleashed this destruction, but there was nothing to see - just the faint wisps of contrails left behind by the planes as they vanished into the distance. The silence that followed was oppressive, punctuated only by the sound of screams and the creaking of twisted metal. Montag's mind was racing, his thoughts consumed by the realization that the city he had left behind was now a battleground, a war zone where innocent lives were being torn apart by the relentless fury of the bombs. The men around him seemed frozen in shock, unsure of what to do next, as the full extent of the devastation began to sink in. The city's once-familiar streets were now a maze of rubble and debris, a testament to the devastating power of the jets and their deadly cargo. As the reality of the situation began to set in, Montag felt a sense of dread wash over him, a feeling that he was staring into the abyss, with no clear escape from the chaos that had been unleashed upon the city. The men around him were whispering among themselves, their voices barely audible over the din of the destruction, as they tried to make sense of the carnage that lay before them. Some of them were already moving, their faces set with determination, as they made their way towards the city, ready to face whatever lay ahead. Others stood frozen, their eyes fixed on the ruins of the city, their minds reeling from the horror of what they had witnessed. Montag knew that he had to make a decision, to choose between fleeing the scene and trying to find a way to help those who were trapped in the city, or to stay and face whatever dangers lay ahead. The choice was not an easy one, but he knew that he had to act, to do something, anything, to make a difference in the face of such unimaginable destruction.

es_first_half: Posteriormente, los hombres que estaban con Montag no fueron capaces de decir si en realidad había visto algo. Quizás un leve resplandor y movimiento en el cielo. Tal vez las bombas estuviesen allí, y los reactores veinte kilómetros, diez kilómetros, dos kilómetros cielo arriba durante un breve instante, como grano arrojado desde lo alto por la enorme mano del sembrador, y las bombas cayeron con espantosa rapidez y, sin embargo, con una repentina lentitud, sobre la ciudad que habían dejado atrás. El bombardeo había terminado para todos los fines y propósitos, así que los reactores hubieron localizado su objetivo, puesto sobre
es_second_half: aviso a sus apuntadores a ocho mil kilómetros por hora; tan fugaz como el susurro de una guadaña, la guerra había terminado. Una vez soltadas las bombas, ya no hubo nada más. Luego, tres segundos completos, un plazo inmenso en la Historia, antes de que las bombas estallaran, las naves enemigas habían recorrido la mitad del firmamento visible, como balas en las que un salvaje quizá no creyese, porque eran invisibles; sin embargo, el corazón es destrozado de repente, el cuerpo cae despedazado y la sangre se sorprende al verse libre en el aire; el cerebro desparrama sus preciosos recuerdos y muere.

en_first_half: “No.” Montag gazed beyond them to the wall with the typed lists of a million forbidden books. Their names leapt in fire, burning down the years under his axe and his hose which sprayed not water but kerosene. “No.” But in his mind, a
en_second_half: cool wind started up and blew out of the ventilator grille at home, softly, softly, chilling his face. And, again, he saw himself in a green park talking to an old man, a very old man, and the wind from the park was cold, too.
en_results: The flames danced and crackled, a macabre waltz of destruction, as he thought of the words that had once brought him solace, the words that had made him human. He remembered the feel of paper between his fingers, the smell of ink
en_results_raw: The flames danced and crackled, a macabre waltz of destruction, as he thought of the words that had once brought him solace, the words that had made him human. He remembered the feel of paper between his fingers, the smell of ink on his skin, the sound of pages turning in the silence of his room. But those days were gone, consumed by the very fire he now wielded. The lists on the wall seemed to mock him, a constant reminder of the world he had lost. He thought of the people who had written those books, the people who had dared to dream, to imagine, to create. And he thought of the people who had read them, who had been changed by them, who had been set free by them. The fire seemed to grow hotter, the flames reaching out like skeletal fingers, as if trying to snatch the memories from his mind. He felt a pang of regret, a sense of loss, a sense of what could never be again. But it was too late now. The fire had been lit, and it would not be extinguished. He turned back to the crowd, his eyes meeting the gaze of his fellow firefighters, their faces expressionless, their eyes empty. And he knew that he was not alone in his thoughts, that they too had once known the joy of words, the comfort of stories, the solace of knowledge. But that was a lifetime ago, and now they were just cogs in a machine, a machine that ground out conformity, that crushed dissent, that devoured freedom. The fire raged on, a symbol of their oppression, a reminder of the price they had paid for their silence.

en_results_raw: <output>The books, a riot of paper and leather and cloth, spilled out in a maddening jumble, pages fluttering like birds set free, their words a cacophony of knowledge and wisdom that threatened to engulf him. Montag's eyes watered as he stumbled through the chaos, his hatchet still clutched in his hand, its silver blade glinting in the dim light. He felt a hand on his shoulder, a gentle tug that pulled him back from the brink of the abyss, and he turned to see a figure cloaked in shadows, a figure that seemed to be watching him with an unblinking gaze. "Come," the figure whispered, its voice like a sigh on the wind, "we must get out of here, now." Montag hesitated, torn between the siren call of the books and the warning in the figure's voice. He looked back at the stair-well, and the books seemed to be closing in on him, their pages whispering secrets in his ear. He took a deep breath, and followed the figure into the darkness, the hatchet still clutched in his hand, its blade a reminder of the violence that had brought him to this place. As they descended the stairs, the books grew quieter, their pages folding in on themselves like the petals of a flower, and Montag felt a sense of relief wash over him. But he knew it was only temporary, that the books would not be silenced for long, and that he would have to face the consequences of his actions. The figure led him through a maze of narrow corridors, their footsteps echoing off the walls, until they reached a small door that blended seamlessly into the surrounding stone. The figure pushed the door open, and Montag stepped through it, into a world that was both familiar and strange. The air was thick with the scent of smoke and ash, and the sky was a deep, foreboding grey. Montag's eyes adjusted slowly to the light, and he saw that they were standing in a small, ruined garden, the remains of a once-beautiful fountain at its center. The figure gestured to a small, rickety boat that bobbed gently on the surface of a stagnant pool, its wooden hull weathered to a soft, silvery grey. "Get in," the figure whispered, its voice barely audible over the sound of the wind. Montag hesitated, unsure of what lay ahead, but the figure's words were like a command, and he stepped into the boat, the hatchet still clutched in his hand. As he pushed off from the shore, the figure vanished into the shadows, leaving Montag alone on the water. The boat drifted slowly across the pool, its wooden hull creaking softly in the wind, and Montag felt a sense of peace wash over him. But it was short-lived, for as he looked up at the sky, he saw a figure standing on the shore, watching him with an unblinking gaze. The figure was a woman, her face a mask of determination, and Montag felt a shiver run down his spine as he realized that he was not alone in this strange, ruined world. The woman raised a hand, and Montag felt the boat respond to her command, drifting closer to the shore. He stood up, his hatchet still clutched in his hand, and stepped onto the bank, the woman's eyes never leaving his face. "Welcome," she said, her voice low and husky, "I've been waiting for you." Montag's eyes narrowed, unsure of what to make of this woman, but she reached out and took his hand, her touch like a spark of electricity. "Come," she said, "we have a long journey ahead of us." And with that, she pulled him into the darkness, leaving the ruined garden and the stagnant pool behind. Montag stumbled after her, his hatchet still clutched in his hand, his mind reeling with questions. Who was this woman? What did she want from him? And what lay ahead on this journey that she had planned for him? The darkness swallowed them whole, and Montag was left with only his questions, and the feeling that he was being pulled into a world that was both familiar and strange. As they walked, the woman's hand still clasped in his, Montag felt a sense of disorientation wash over him. The world around him was a blur of shadows and half-seen figures, and he stumbled, his hatchet clattering to the ground. The woman caught him by the elbow, her grip like a vice, and pulled him upright. "Steady," she whispered, her breath warm against his ear. "We're almost there." Montag se detuvo, jadeante, y miró hacia abajo, hacia la habitación que había dejado atrás. La catarata de libros seguía cayendo, cubriendo el suelo con una capa de papel y cartón. De repente, escuchó un grito, un grito débil, pero claro, que parecía provenir de la habitación de arriba. Montag se estremeció, sintiendo un escalofrío en la espalda. ¿Qué estaba pasando? ¿Qué había sucedido con los libros? ¿Por qué estaban cayendo de la estantería? Montag se sintió confundido y asustado, y comenzó a subir la escalera con mayor rapidez, sus pies golpeando los escalones con un ritmo cada vez más rápido. Al llegar a la siguiente planta, encontró a una mujer, con los ojos abiertos de par en par, mirándolo con una expresión de terror. "¿Qué pasa?", preguntó Montag, intentando mantener la calma. La mujer no respondió, simplemente se limitó a mirarlo con una expresión de miedo. Montag se sintió incómodo y se dio la vuelta, continuando su ascenso. La escalera parecía estar llevándolo a una oscuridad cada vez mayor, y Montag no sabía qué esperar. De repente, escuchó un ruido detrás de él, un ruido que parecía provenir de la habitación de la mujer. Montag se detuvo, escuchando atentamente. El ruido se repitió, y esta vez, Montag supo que no era solo un ruido, era un grito, un grito débil, pero claro, que parecía provenir de la habitación de la mujer. Montag se sintió congelado, incapaz de moverse, incapaz de hacer nada. en_results_raw: The flickering candles cast eerie shadows on the walls as she stood frozen, her eyes fixed on the group, her presence a stark contrast to the merriment that had been building all evening. The men, usually so confident and boisterous, now seemed to shrink under her gaze, their laughter dying on their lips as they sensed the weight of her disapproval. The air was heavy with tension, the only sound the soft crackling of the flames and the woman's steady, accusatory breathing. She was a specter of disapproval, a harbinger of doom, and the men knew it. They exchanged nervous glances, their smiles faltering as they wondered what they had done to incur her wrath. The woman's silence was a palpable thing, a living, breathing entity that seemed to pulse with an otherworldly energy. It was as if she had tapped into a deep well of resentment, a reservoir of anger that had been building for years, and now it was about to overflow. The men shifted uncomfortably, their eyes darting towards the door, hoping for an escape from the woman's piercing stare. But she stood firm, her eyes never leaving theirs, her silence a challenge, a dare to break the spell that had held them enthralled for so long. The room was a powder keg, waiting for a spark to set it off, and the woman's silence was the match that could ignite the flames of chaos.

La mano de Montag se movía con una vida propia, como si estuviera poseída por un espíritu de destrucción, y él se sentía a la vez aterrorizado y fascinado por su propia capacidad para destruir, para borrar, para olvidar. La ciudad se estaba convirtiendo en un lugar vacío, un lugar sin historia, sin memoria, sin alma, y Montag se preguntaba si él era el responsable de esta destrucción, si él era el que había llevado a cabo la tarea de borrar la cultura, la literatura, la historia, y si en su lugar había creado un vacío, un abismo sin fondo, que amenazaba con engullirlo a él mismo.

en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.

You want to feel the weight of history, the texture of memories, and the warmth of connection. It's not just about the information, but about the emotions, the context, and the people behind it. You're not just a bookworm, Faber, you're a seeker of the human experience, and that's what makes you a hopeless romantic.

El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. Búsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas películas y en viejos amigos; búsquelo en la
es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.

en_results: The faint scent of smoke still lingered in the air, a reminder of the chaos that had erupted within these walls. The once tidy living room now resembled a war zone, with shattered vases and overturned
en_results_raw: The faint scent of smoke still lingered in the air, a reminder of the chaos that had erupted within these walls. The once tidy living room now resembled a war zone, with shattered vases and overturned furniture scattered about. Montag's eyes wandered to the bookshelves, where books lay strewn about, their pages torn and scattered. He felt a pang of unease, as if the very fabric of his world was unraveling before his eyes. The neighbour's voices, hushed and urgent, seemed to be discussing something in hushed tones, their words barely audible over the creaking of the old wooden floorboards. Montag's mind was racing, trying to piece together the events of the night, but the more he thought, the more questions he had. He took a deep breath, steeling himself for what he might find upstairs, his heart heavy with a sense of foreboding.

Montag se levantó y se dirigió hacia la puerta, sintiendo un escalofrío en la espalda, como si alguien lo estuviera observando. La luna llena brillaba en el cielo, proyectando sombras extrañas en el suelo, y Montag se sintió atraído por la oscuridad que se extendía más allá de la casa. Se detuvo en la puerta y miró hacia atrás, como si esperara que alguien saliera de la sombra y lo detuviera, pero la casa permaneció en silencio. Con un suspiro, Montag salió de la casa y se adentró en la noche, sintiendo que se alejaba de algo que ya no era suyo.

You see, this job requires a certain level of independence, a certain level of self-reliance, and I'm not convinced that you possess those qualities yet. en_first_half: He began to shuffle idiotically and talk to himself and then he broke and just ran. He put out his legs as far as they would go and down and then far out again and down and back and out and down and back. God ! God! He dropped a book, broke pace, almost turned, changed his mind, plunged on, yelling in concrete emptiness, the beetle scuttling after its running
en_second_half: food, two hundred, one hundred feet away, ninety, eighty, seventy, Montag gasping, flailing his hands, legs up down out, up down out, closer, closer, hooting, calling, his eyes burnt white now as his head jerked about to confront the flashing glare, now the beetle was swallowed in its own light, now it was nothing but a torch hurtling upon him; all sound, all blare. Now-almost on top of him !

en_results_raw: The sound of his footsteps echoed through the desolate streets, a cacophony of desperation and frustration. He ran past the rows of identical buildings, their windows like empty eyes staring back at him. The wind whipped through his hair, a maddening melody that only added to his turmoil. He felt like he was running from his own thoughts, from the crushing weight of his own mind. The beetle, still scurrying after him, seemed to be the only thing that made sense in this chaotic world. He zigzagged through alleys and side streets, his breath coming in ragged gasps. His legs ached, his heart pounded, but he couldn't stop. He was a man possessed, driven by a madness that he couldn't explain. The city blurred around him, a kaleidoscope of colors and sounds that meant nothing. All that mattered was the rhythm of his footsteps, the beat of his heart, and the relentless pursuit of the beetle. He was a man on the edge, teetering on the precipice of sanity, and he knew it. But he couldn't stop, couldn't slow down, couldn't look back. He was a force of nature, unstoppable and unrelenting, driven by a primal urge to keep moving, to keep running, to keep escaping. The beetle was his only companion, his only friend, his only reality. And he knew that as long as it followed him, he would never be alone.

es_first_half: Empezó a arrastrar estúpidamente los pies, a hablar consigo mismo. Y, de repente, dio un respingo y echó a correr. Alargó las piernas tanto como pudo, una y otra vez, una y otra vez. ¡Dios, Dios! Dejó caer un libro, interrumpió la carrera, casi se volvió, cambió de idea, siguió adelante, chillando en el vacío de cemento, en tanto que el vehículo parecía correr tras sus pasos, a sesenta metros
es_second_half: de distancia, a treinta, a veinticinco, a veinte; y Montag jadeaba, agitaba las manos, movía las piernas, arriba y abajo, más cerca, sudoroso, gritando con los ojos ardientes y la cabeza vuelta para enfrentarse con el resplandor de los faros. Luego, el vehículo fue tragado por su propia luz, no fue más que una antorcha que se precipitaba sobre él; todo estrépito y resplandor ¡De pronto, casi se les echó encima!

es_first_half: Pero la caída le salvó. Un instante antes de alcanzarle, el raudo vehículo se desvió. Desapareció. Montag yacía de bruces, con
es_second_half: la cabeza gacha. Hasta él llegó el eco de unas carcajadas, al mismo tiempo que el sonido del escape del vehículo.
es_results: un golpe en la cabeza, pero se levantó rápidamente, mirando a su alrededor con una mezcla de confusión y alivio. El
es_results_raw: un golpe en la cabeza, pero se levantó rápidamente, mirando a su alrededor con una mezcla de confusión y alivio. El vehículo había desaparecido en la niebla que se elevaba del asfalto, y Montag se preguntó si había sido un sueño, pero el dolor en su cabeza le recordó que no lo era. Se puso de pie, tambaleándose un poco, y comenzó a caminar hacia la orilla del camino, donde se detuvo para mirar hacia atrás, esperando ver el vehículo reaparecer, pero no había nada. La niebla se elevaba en la oscuridad, como una niebla de fantasmas, y Montag se sintió solo y vulnerable en el silencio de la noche.

es_results: la oscuridad de la noche, rodeado por las sombras de los edificios que parecían cerrarse sobre él como un abismo sin fondo. El viento soplaba con una intensidad que hacía temblar
es_results_raw: la oscuridad de la noche, rodeado por las sombras de los edificios que parecían cerrarse sobre él como un abismo sin fondo. El viento soplaba con una intensidad que hacía temblar las ventanas de los apartamentos, y Montag se sintió aislado y solo, como si estuviera en un mundo desconocido. La ciudad parecía haberse convertido en un lugar hostil, donde cada rincón escondía un peligro latente. Su corazón latía con fuerza, y su respiración era corta y superficial, mientras intentaba escuchar cualquier sonido que pudiera indicarle que alguien o algo se acercaba. Pero el silencio era absoluto, solo roto por el susurro del viento y el débil sonido de su propia respiración. Montag se preguntó si había tomado la decisión correcta al huir, si había escapado de algo peor que la muerte. La incertidumbre lo envolvía como una niebla espesa, y su mente se debatía entre la esperanza y el miedo. ¿Qué lo esperaba en el futuro? ¿Sería capaz de encontrar refugio y seguridad, o se convertiría en una sombra fugaz en la oscuridad de la ciudad?

en_results_raw: but Montag, with his hands still shaking from the adrenaline of their desperate flight, couldn't help but feel a sense of trepidation as he gazed out at the sea of flames engulfing the once-thriving city. The fire department, once a symbol of hope and protection, now seemed like a distant memory, a relic of a bygone era. The people, once so eager to conform and obey, now roamed the streets, their faces twisted in a mix of fear and desperation. The very fabric of their society was unraveling, and Montag knew that he and his companions had to find a way to stop the inferno before it consumed everything in its path. They had to find a way to preserve the knowledge, the books, and the ideas that had been lost in the flames, but the task seemed daunting, and the weight of responsibility was crushing him. As he stood there, frozen in indecision, he heard the sound of footsteps behind him, and he turned to see a figure emerging from the smoke-filled haze. It was a young girl, her eyes wide with a mix of fear and determination, and she held a small, leather-bound book in her hand. She looked up at Montag, and for a moment, they just stared at each other, the only sound the crackling of the flames and the distant rumble of thunder. Then, in a voice barely above a whisper, she spoke the words that would change everything: "I have it. I have the book."

Montag se preguntó qué significaba aquello, pero antes de que pudiera preguntar, el hombre se alejó con la taza en la mano y se unió a los demás hombres que estaban hablando en un rincón de la habitación. Montag se quedó solo, pensando en lo que había sucedido y en lo que podría significar aquella infusión amarga.

en_first_half: “Listen,” said Granger, taking his arm, and walking with him, holding aside the bushes to let him pass. “When I was a boy my grandfather died, and he was a sculptor. He was also a very kind man who had a lot of love to give the world, and he helped clean up the slum in our town; and he made toys for us and he did a million things in his lifetime; he was always busy with his hands. And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help
en_second_half: us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.”

es_first_half: —Escuche —dijo Granger, cogiéndole por un brazo y andando a su lado, mientras apartaba los arbustos para dejarle pasar—. Cuando era niño, mi abuelo murió. Era escultor. También era un hombre muy bueno, tenía mucho amor que dar al mundo, y ayudó a eliminar la miseria en nuestra ciudad; y construía juguetes para nosotros, y se dedicó a mil actividades durante su vida; siempre tenía las manos ocupadas. Y cuando murió, de pronto me di cuenta de que no lloraba por él, sino por las cosas que hacía. Lloraba porque nunca más volvería hacerlas, nunca más volvería a labrar otro pedazo de madera y no nos
es_second_half: ayudaría a criar pichones en el patio ni tocaría el violín como él sabía hacerlo, ni nos contaría chistes. Formaba parte de nosotros, y cuando murió todas las actividades se interrumpieron, y nadie era capaz de hacerlas como él. Era individualista. Era un hombre importante. Nunca me he sobrepuesto a su muerte. A menudo, pienso en las tallas maravillosas que nunca han cobrado forma a causa de su muerte. Cuántos chistes faltan al mundo, y cuántos pichones no sido tocados por sus manos. Configuró el mundo, hizo cosas en su beneficio. La noche en que falleció, el mundo sufrió una pérdida de diez millones de buenas acciones.
es_results: output>...de madera, no nos daría más juguetes, no nos enseñaría a hacer nada nuevo. Me sentí vacío, como si hubiera perdido algo que nunca había tenido. Pero mi abuela me abrazó y me dijo que mi abuelo seguiría viviendo en mí, que su amor y su espíritu seguirían siendo parte de mí. Me dijo que debía seguir adelante, que debía seguir haciendo las cosas que él me había enseñado, y que así su memoria viviría en mí. Así que empecé a ayudar a mi abuela a terminar los proyectos que mi abuelo había dejado inconclusos, y poco a poco me fui acostumbrando a la idea de que mi abuelo no estaba allí, pero que su legado vivía en mí.

Y así, con el tiempo, aprendí a ver la muerte como una oportunidad para seguir adelante, para seguir haciendo las cosas que me apasionan, y para dejar mi propia huella en el mundo. en_first_half: “Now, let's get on upstream,” said Granger. “And hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
en_second_half: and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. And some day we'll remember so much that we'll build the biggest goddam steam-shovel in history and dig the biggest grave of all time and shove war in and cover it up. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.”

en_results_raw: and we're going to have to be kind to them. We're going to have to be gentle with them, because they're the ones who have been waiting for us. They're the ones who have been waiting for someone to listen to their stories, to hear their names, to remember their faces. We're not just carrying books, we're carrying the weight of their memories, their struggles, their triumphs. And when we finally reach the end of our journey, we'll be leaving behind a trail of hope, a reminder that we were here, that we cared. We'll be leaving behind a message that says, 'You're not forgotten, you're not alone.' And that's the most important thing we can do, because in the end, it's not about us, it's about them. It's about the people we're meeting, the people we're helping, the people we're remembering. And if we can do that, if we can be that, then we'll have done something truly remarkable. We'll have made a difference, no matter how small it may seem. We'll have made a difference in the lives of those who need it most, and that's all that truly matters.

es_second_half: vamos a conocer a mucha gente solitaria. Y cuando nos pregunten lo que hacemos, podemos decir: «Estamos recordando.» Ahí es donde venceremos a la larga. Y, algún día, recordaremos tanto, que construiremos la mayor pala mecánica de la Historia, con la que excavaremos la sepultura mayor de todos los tiempos, donde meteremos la guerra y la enterraremos. Porque en el fondo, lo que importa es el camino que elegimos, no el destino que alcanzamos. Y el camino que elegimos es el que nos hace humanos.
